skill.name: concept-scaffolding
skill.description: Design progressive concept scaffolding with cognitive load management. Use when breaking down complex concepts into learnable steps for educational content.

skill.author: 92Bilal26

security_audit.summary: Prompt-based educational skill containing only instructional methodology documentation. No executable code, scripts, network calls, file system access, or command execution. Static findings are false positives triggered by educational terminology being misinterpreted as security patterns.

content.value_statement: Complex concepts overwhelm learners when presented incorrectly. This skill applies cognitive load theory to design step-by-step progressions that match learner proficiency, ensuring concepts build on prerequisites with appropriate scaffolding at each stage.
actual_capabilities: Diagnose what makes a concept cognitively demanding and identify prerequisites
Design 3-7 step learning progressions based on cognitive load limits
Match scaffolding intensity to learner proficiency (A1-A2 beginner, B1 intermediate, B2+ advanced)
Create worked examples followed by validation checkpoints
Apply progressive complexity pattern (simple to realistic to complex)
limitations: Does not create actual course materials or exercises
Does not assess individual learners in real-time
Does not integrate with learning management systems
Provides scaffolding frameworks, not finished curricula

use_cases.title: Structure technical tutorials
use_cases.description: Design step-by-step progressions for teaching programming concepts like decorators, closures, or async patterns.

use_cases.title: Create learning pathways
use_cases.description: Break down complex topics into digestible chunks that respect working memory constraints.

use_cases.title: Design AI-assisted training
use_cases.description: Determine where AI should explain concepts versus where learners should practice independently.

prompt_templates.title: Scaffold basic concept
prompt_templates.prompt: Scaffold [CONCEPT] for beginner learners (A1-A2 level). Include complexity diagnosis, 4-step progression with cognitive load per step, and checkpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate breakdown
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a 5-step scaffolding plan for [TOPIC] at intermediate level (B1). Apply the simple-realistic-complex progression pattern with worked examples.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced concept structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create scaffolding architecture for [ADVANCED TOPIC] for B2+ learners. Include dependency mapping, load budget per step, and integration with future concepts.

prompt_templates.title: Layer-specific design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design Layer 2 (AI-assisted) scaffolding for [CONCEPT]. Specify where AI explains complex patterns versus where learners practice independently. Include convergence loops.

output_examples.input: Scaffold Python decorators for intermediate learners
output: Step 1: Functions as Objects (15 min) - 2 new concepts, heavy scaffolding
Step 2: Functions Returning Functions (20 min) - 3 new concepts, worked example
Step 3: The Wrapper Pattern (25 min) - 4 new concepts, AI explains complexity
Step 4: Decorator Syntax (20 min) - 2 new concepts, light scaffolding
Step 5: Decorators with Arguments (10 min, optional) - 3 new concepts, stretch goal

best_practices: Calculate cognitive load per step rather than dividing content arbitrarily
Always show worked examples before asking learners to practice
Validate understanding with checkpoints after each step before proceeding
anti_patterns: Creating exactly 5 steps because that is conventional rather than optimal
Explaining a concept then immediately asking learners to apply without examples
Using the same scaffolding intensity for beginners and advanced learners

faq.question: What proficiency levels does this skill support?
faq.answer: A1-A2 beginners (2-4 concepts per step), B1 intermediate (3-5 concepts), B2+ advanced (4-7 concepts without artificial limits).

faq.question: How many steps should a scaffolding plan contain?
faq.answer: Optimal range is 3-7 steps. Too few creates cognitive leaps; too many causes fragmentation. Design based on load, not convention.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with other learning skills?
faq.answer: Yes. Works with learning-objectives, technical-clarity, skills-proficiency-mapper, code-example-generator, and book-scaffolding.

faq.question: What data does this skill access?
faq.answer: This is a prompt-based skill with no file access, network calls, or data collection. It operates on user-provided concepts only.

faq.question: Why is my scaffolding too complex for learners?
faq.answer: Check cognitive load per step. Beginners should handle 2-4 new concepts maximum. Add more checkpoints and worked examples if learners struggle.

faq.question: How is this different from creating a simple list of steps?
faq.answer: Traditional lists ignore cognitive load. This skill applies evidence-based principles: load budgeting, worked examples first, dependency ordering, and validation checkpoints.
